text.0: these who wear hairknots on the right the movers of holy thought whiterobed have won me over.
text.1: i warned the men when from the grass i raised me not from afar can my vasisthas help you.
text.2: with soma they brought indra from a distance over vaisanta from the strong libation.
text.3: indra preferred vasisthas to the soma pressed by the son of vayata pasadyumna.
text.4: so verily with these he crossed the river in company with these he slaughtered bheda.
text.5: so in the fight with the ten kings vasisthas did indra help sudās through your devotions.
text.6: i gladly men i with prayer prayed by our fathers have fixed your axle ye shall not be injured.
text.7: since when ye sang aloud the sakvari verses vasisthas ye invigorated indra.
text.8: like thirsty men they looked to heaven in battle with the ten kings surrounded and imploring.
text.9: then indra heard vasiṣṭha as he praised him and gave the trtsus ample room and freedom.
text.10: like sticks and staves wherewith they drive the cattle stripped bare the bharatas were found defenceless.
text.11: vasiṣṭha then became their chief and leader then widely were the trtsus clans extended.
text.12: three fertilize the worlds with genial moisture three noble creatures cast a light before them.
text.13: three that give warmth to all attend the morning all these have they discovered these vasisthas.
text.14: like the suns growing glory is their splendour and like the seas is their unflathomed greatness.
text.15: their course is like the winds your laud vasisthas can never be attained by any other.
text.16: they with perceptions of the heart in secret resort to that which spreads a thousand branches.
text.17: the apsaras brought hither the vasisthas wearing the vesture spun for them by yama.
text.18: a form of lustre springing from the lightning wast thou when varuṇa and mitra saw thee.
text.19: tliy one and only birth was then vasiṣṭha when from thy stock agastya brought thee hither.
text.20: born of their love for urvasi vasiṣṭha thou priest art son of varuṇa and mitra.
text.21: and as a fallen drop in heavenly fervour all the gods laid thee on a lotusblossorn.
text.22: he thinker knower both of earth and heaven endowed with many a gift bestowing thousands.
text.23: destined to wear the vesture spun by yama sprang from the apsaras to life vasiṣṭha.
text.24: born at the sacrifice urged by adorations both with a common flow bedewed the pitcher.
text.25: then from the midst thereof there rose up māna and thence they say was born the sage vasiṣṭha.
text.26: he brings the bearer of the laud and sāman first shall he speak bringing the stone for pressing.
text.27: with grateful hearts in reverence approach him to you o pratrdas vasiṣṭha cometh.
